title: SB 1412
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 89724 of the Education Code is amended to appropriate money for the support of the California State University from various sources, including the sale of publications, student fees, and other agreements, without regard to fiscal year. Money received under specific sections of the Civil Code and Education Code shall be used for student scholarships and loans as per trustee regulations. Additionally, funds from other specified sections may be invested in eligible securities with trustee approval. Money received under Sections 89720 and 89721, and pursuant to Section 2080.8 of the Civil Code, can be invested in mutual funds or real estate investment trusts with trustee approval. Earnings from these investments must be used for purposes outlined by the trustees. All money received under specified sections can be invested with trustee approval and earnings must be used for outlined purposes. Money received under other sections shall augment support appropriation to California State University for the applicable fiscal year. All money received from the sale or disposition of real or personal property acquired by a California State University campus through gift, devise, or donation is appropriated to the trustees for capital outlay for property acquisition and improvement, in addition to any other funds allocated by the Legislature. The trustees of California State University can use money from the sale of property for capital outlay with approval from the Director of Finance. The funds will supplement the university's current support or capital outlay budget as designated by the trustees before depositing the money in the State Treasury. Section 89725 of the Education Code allows the trustees of California State University to deposit grants, revenues, and funds for research, workshops, conferences, and special projects into the California State University Special Projects Fund. These funds are appropriated for the operation and development of such projects without regard to fiscal year. The trustees of California State University can deposit funds into the Special Projects Fund for projects, with authority to establish rules and procedures for fund operation. Expenditures must comply with these rules, and audits will be conducted as deemed appropriate by the Audits Division of the Department of Finance. The California State University Special Projects Fund allows for investments in eligible securities or mutual funds, with all earnings collected by the Treasurer and deposited back into the fund. The trustees may also invest in securities not listed in the Government Code with the advice of a designated committee. The California State University Special Projects Fund allows investments in eligible securities or mutual funds, with earnings deposited back into the fund. A committee, consisting of individuals with investment expertise, oversees investments not listed in the Government Code. The total amount invested in such securities shall not exceed specified amounts for each fiscal year. The trustees of the California State University Special Projects Fund must provide quarterly investment performance reports and an annual report to the Legislature and Department of Finance. Additional earnings from investments not listed in the Government Code must be used for capital outlay or maintenance, not for ongoing operations. Requests for funds to compensate for investment losses in such securities are prohibited. The trustees of the California State University Special Projects Fund must not use investment losses from certain securities to justify tuition increases or course reductions.
